number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8
												One of the still standing RTS games from the old era. Empire Earth is dead, Age of Empires is dead. Long live Company of Heroes! The RTS system used in the Company of Heroes gameplay is vastly different from the other popular RTS of its era. It is highly recommended to go through the tutorial (as I did not the first time I played it) because the way you control and create units it is based on squads, and that gives the gameplay a lot more dynamism when you are openly battling the other factions and taking territories. The graphics are quite amazing, with destructible environment. You can even zoom in to see each of your units! Gameplay-wise this is a highly strategical game in which the occupation of territories actually holds a real value, compared to other RTS. So remember to have one or two squads around the corner ready to surprise the enemy, as they may not be expecting you to have rigged with explosives the bridge their tanks are in! This is a highly replayable, highly entertaining, time consuming RTS. Before I bought it in Steam I had the disc (oh, such times!) and I had some pretty amazing, long lasting matches which sometimes had to be called off because well... we needed to eat and let the sun outside hit us. Either way, in 2017 it still is a terrific game to be playing, either this one or the sequel, but keep up the support for this series!10/10Buy it, play it and don't regret it.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
 Company Of Heroes 2006 Genre: Rts, HistoricalActivity: MinimalWorkshop: NoDLC: YesUser reviews: 96% positiveMetacritic 93/100 Brief Description A semi-classic genre defining WW2 Real-time-strategy game with a sequal which means its not as active anymore.  My first impressions I recently got this game for $3.24 and honestly, I don't regret it. I got into the gameplay with the first hour of playing. There are so many play styles and game modes. 4v4, 3v3, 2v2, 1v1 with an assortment of AI difficulties, 60+ Maps, 2 gamemodes and many unique factions to choose from. I chose to do a full tank squad that consisted of 10 tanks that would dominate. The commanders options are pretty cool but get old quite quick. Pros 1. Great gameplay2. Multiple units to play with3. Wide varient of maps4. Battles5. Single-Player/skirmish6. Replayable7. The graphics have aged well8. Commander mode (Air/Infantry/Armoured focus modes)9. Cheap10. Amazing unit strats and commands Cons 1. Crashing is common2. 16 gig download but 7.6 gig download for the new steam version?3. Only 2 fractions without dlc4. Multiplayer is slightly dead5. Annoying camera controls6. Strange money system7. Tedious gameplay that can drag on if something stupid happens8. Fullscreen is bugged9. CoH 2 is out and only a bit more expensive ($8 price difference)10. Tanks dont always follow commands Overall I love this game due to the amount of maps and units. I personally give it 8.4/10 Extras  There is a HL2 mod that is basically a reskin of this game. Lambda wars, at this time the game is in Beta so it isn't finished obv, alot of things with be getting added such as Vehicles, more units and more factions. So far its combine vs rebels. Also its free!Its really cool playing from the perspective of a rebel/combine commander from the Hl2 universe.Also, hl2 being based in the future means more advanced tools such as invisible scanners, headcrab launchers, dark matter cannon, striders and more strange futuristic weaponry/items.Get it here

content:
Posted: November 25, 2010
												Company of Gyros is Relic's bold attempt to bring their experience on the sublime Homeworld 2 to the more down-to-earth genre of restaurant simulations. As the CEO of Gyros 'n Stuff, you control the national (and eventually multinational) policies of your gigantic corporation, but the game also allows you to micromanage various franchise owners if you wish. This is its greatest strength, because franchises in different regions have different challenges and objectives, and the higher level gameplay mirrors this, so that by spending time playing as these different franchises, you'll learn about the "realities on the ground" that are so crucial to success as a CEO. The endgame gets pretty bogged down because the game starts throwing lawsuits at you over the most tedious, petty details, and God help you if you actually did something REALLY bad. If your very first restaurant 10 years ago served ONE half-rat, half-lamb gyro on accident, you'll probably lose, long after you've quicksaved.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												i HIGHLY recommend this game, probably my favourite RTS game of all time! In the game, you choose between 2 sides: the United States or the Wehrmacht (German), and if you have the DLC for the game, you can also choose: The Commen Wealth or The Panzer Elite (which is pretty much the regular German team, but with different and/or more tank options and less infantry). The game includes a Singleplayer Campaign (which is expanded if you have the DLC), and great Multiplayer gameplay, with a bunch of maps to choose from, some maps being small for 1v1 matches, and some being massive for 4v4 matches. another thing really good about the multiplayer is most of the time the community is really good (of course, every once in a while you run into that guy who thinks he runs the show). ALSO, if u do happen to get bored after a while of playing the same thing over and over, there are LOTS of mods to choose from, for example: Modern Combat mod, Eastern Front mod and the Blitzkrieg mod. To sum it all up, excellent game! ARMOR IS GOOD TO GO!-------10/10 Shermans

So I would absoloutly NOT recommend this game unless you prefer playing against and with AI or with friends and campaing mode. I honestly think this game is awesome, but it's just that there is a few things in the game that should be changed. This may sound like a bad review, but the pros outnumber the cons. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2013
												This is an outstanding strategy and tactics game! You never know how a battle will end and the battle can swing back and forth at a moments notice. Every little detail counts in this game, as simply facing a machine gun a certain direction can have it either hold off waves and waves of infantry or become easily overrun by a single squad of riflemen.Units are also a great aspect of this game, as every faction has tons of unique and individual units, and each army feels completely different from the others. These units all complement each other very nicely, and no sole unit can win the game. You must use your units to work together to defeat the enemy.Visually and graphically this game is very pleasing as well. Graphics are nice and detailed and the terrain is fully destructable. Sound is also great in this game, with especially great voice acting for all of the units keeping the game from becoming completely dark and depressing, with units occasionally cracking truly humorous remarks.Overall, this is a great game for anyone who likes strategy and tactics, and if you aren't sure if you want to get the second one yet due to it's still high price(although it is just as good as this game but even more improved) this is a great game to get into real time tactics.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Wow, where do I start with this masterpiece...Company of Heroes is a game that's hard to categorize. A hybrid space sim/racer/fps/jrpg didn't seem doable, but Relic Entertainment somehow pulled it off. The gameplay requires a lot of skill from the player, but rewards smart play more than most modern games. The boss fights are all brilliantly executed, and the puzzles are a perfect balance of challenging and enjoyable. An edgy, thought provoking plot about modern imperialism and its effects on the geopolitical landscape in the year 2045 could easily have fallen flat, but writers Steven King and Neil Degrasse Tyson have managed to create a terrifying dystopia in which anything seems possible. This gives Company of Heroes a heightened sense of terror and surrealism that sets it apart from the rest.I only have a couple of complaints. The graphics on level 3 definitely need some tightening up, the 3rd fetch quest you do for the "Horse" character becomes a bit tedious, and the all-rap soundtrack felt a bit inapproriate considering the serene environments, particularly in the hell level. This isn't enough to put a damper on the overall experience, though. Solid gameplay and a cartoonish aesthetic coupled with whimsical minigames and a surprisingly deep sandbox mode make Company of Heroes an easy GOTY contender. The boss fights are all brilliantly executed, and the puzzles were the perfect balance of challenging and enjoyable.Raccoon/Turtle

												Great game for lovers of RTS genre, you don't have to gather resouces but the resources you do have is a challenge to manage; buy a tank when you should've bought a AT gun? content:
Posted: April 14, 2013
												If you're looking for an RTS that can be enjoyable without having to Zerg Rush your way through gameplay, then look no further.  CoH is one of those few memorable strategy games that puts all others of it's genre to shame with it's dynamic game mechanics, impressive visual and audio (considering it's back from '06), and enticingly realistic scenarios.  A must-have for any fans of the more well-known RTS games such as Age of Empires, Starcraft/Warcraft, and Warhammer. Truly a sound investment that couldn't be wrong for anyone, I'd personally give this game a 9.5/10. (-.5 for a few minor flaws that could easily be overlooked)

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												Really a great game, unlike most Real Time Stragety games, Company Of Heroes forces you to be tatical, plan, and use your resources sparingly. You can't simply throw your basic unit at the enemy base until they eventually break down. You must use your rifle men to take out small squadrons of of the enemy, your snipers to sneak up on the mortar team that has the rest of your men pinned, and your tank to blow that MG nest sky high and keep it from plastering your soldiers. Then as you close on the enemy base, you must use your own mortar teams to take out the anti tank units that will quickly destroy your heavy calvary. When your men are under heavy fire, they wont stand there and take it, they will drop down, get pinned, and be unable to attack. Yet if you place them in good cover, (which you can actually pick where they will take cover) and the enemy is exposed on advancement they will be the ones pinned. This is really a great game, and well worth the money.BUY THIS CRAP!

												This is one of the most overrated games I have played in many years. The praise given by critics and gamers to Company of Heroes is truly alarming. To play the game, you will be forced into signing up and logging into a Relic-Online account with your CD key. It doesn't matter if you're playing single player. Relic forces you into this DRM style process that is not even listed with Steam. This is absolutely unnacceptable and I feel misinformed by Steam and Relic. Relic had another idiotic idea. Menus for all three standalone Company of Heroes games are included, but locked. There are also two training missions from the second standalone game that appear, but are locked as well. Ridiculous. Upon first impressions (first four missions), the tactics appear to be slow, unrealistic, lacking in response, and surprisingly linear for a real-time strategy game. I am somewhat shocked, as this game has secured much hype over the years. The AI (of your own units and the enemy) is amazingly simple and limited. The units often have a hard time with your directions, and all units appear to be suffering from Alzheimer's disease. The AI is simply not up to standard. Many of your troops stand or sit around during a large generalized firefight, or have extremely bad shot accuracy. Saving and loading times (especially) are unexcusably long even with a modern computer. After you quit the game, Steam uploads/synchronizes several hundred megs each time. I understand I can turn this off. My complaint is the amount of space the Company of Heroes save games occupy without allowing you to delete previously saved games. Company of Heroes does not make this simple save game housekeeping possible. The game has some serious sound volume troubles in general, as it is abnormally low. Between the live action portion and the cutscenes, this problem is most serious. The cutscenes are much lower in volume in comparison. You will be restricted to constructing a very small amount of buildings (six) and only seven types of infantry troops. If the aforementioned buildings and units were more extensive with their usage and utility, I would not have much to gripe about. In reality, you will find that what you have access to is quite abridged for a game that came out in 2006. From the fifth mission on, things do get better and a tiny bit more exciting, even though it will continue to be almost an exact repetition of the first four missions. The gameplay is abbreviated, strikingly dull, laggard, close to being boring, and with little to no excitement. You select your squad(s), point them in a certain direction, select some inexstensive actions, watch some mildly interesting battle take place until the enemy troops are all dead, then capture a strategic point. That's it. There is really not much else to it. Even if the mission objectives change from mission to mission, the means you will exercise to achieve those goals will be the same. Construct buildings, generate units, upgrade, take over strategic points, repair units, replenish units, and then repeat. Once again, that's it. Company of Heroes does not provide the player with any fresh real-time strategy scope. This clumsy piece of software also managed to crash multiple times during the final mission.Company of Heroes is okay.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
Product received for free
												TL;DR- just buy it, it's a classic RTS, shame on you if you don't. Classic Real Time Strategy game. If you're new to real time strategy games, then I highly reccomend , and if you're an RTS vet, then you should still play. It's an excellent exciting game with well designed missions and decent "breifings" without too many constraints. I always feel like rts campaigns force you to play a certain way, but I don't have that problem with company of heroes I'll list my pro's and cons.Pros:-Dynamic gameplay, no feeling like mission after mission with a repeitive task. It feels like a natural progression.-Decent Campaign Length-In-game/In-game rendered cutscenes (Can be seen as a con, but I really like it. It makes you feel more invested when you zoom in)-Infantry can pick up weapons or man weapons that can turn into seperate units-It's during world war 2.Cons:-I ran into 3 glitches along the way. They're really simple to fix by just doing a quick google search for thr info.-Not too much unit variety, but in my opinion is made up for by the ability to man weapons and gain unit types by picking up items. You can also do this with weapons dropped by enemies.-seperate version for multiplayer is buggy af-F***ing annoying engineers with flame throwers sneaking behind your lines-limiting population cap

content:
Posted: November 16, 2013
												Delivering a visceral WWII gaming experience, Company of Heroes redefines real time strategy gaming by bringing the sacrifice of heroic soldiers, war-ravaged environments, and dynamic battlefields to life. Beginning with the D-Day Invasion of Normandy, players lead squads of Allied soldiers into battle against the German war machine through some of the most pivotal battles of WWII. Through a rich single player campaign, players experience the cinematic intensity and bravery of ordinary soldiers thrust into extraordinary events. - A Cinematic Single Player Experience that captures the turmoil of WWII as never before. Advanced squad AI brings your soldiers to life as they interact with the changing environment, take cover, and execute advanced squad tactics to eliminate all enemy opposition. - Stunning Visuals - Relic's next generation cutting-edge engine provides graphic quality and a physics driven world that is unprecedented in an RTS. - Environmental Strategy - Real-time physics and a completely destructible environment guarantee no two battles ever play out in the same way. Destroy anything and re-shape the battlefield! Use buildings and terrain to your advantage, or deny them to the enemy. 2-8 Player Multiplayer Competition via LAN or Internet - Go online with friends and join the ultimate battle of Axis versus Allies.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												overall, I'm not impressed.Listen: I should not be able to throw infantry wave after infantry wave at a Panzer while drunk on a Saturday night and not be penalized. I beat the missions and got a few medals along the way, but I was never challenged, because (except for defensive missions), I knew none of it mattered. So what I lost the entire 5th US Army in an assault on a portapotty? Sucks to be their widows. I beat the mission and was on to the next. My lack of competence had no feedback. I had no want to get better, and no way to know that I sucked besides my own criticisms.It has good mechanics, sure. Troops go where I tell them to go, and shoot at what I want them to shoot at, but being smart has no real merit. Flanking means nothing unless you toss a grenade, because whether the Nazis are facing towards you or away from you, it doesn't matter. Your soliders shoot the same and don't take cover except or machine gun fire.Basically, play Close Combat: Invasion Normandy. If you suck at it, you won't win, and if you win, it's because you don't suck at it.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												I can see that by "not recommending" this version on Steam people will say your review is not helpful purely because of that reason- the actual review itself be damned. Because of that let me recommend this game but put a huge disclaimer about this Steam version of CoH right at the start:***What this game SAYS it is giving you and what is actually SOLD are two different items. LAN is not included in this sale; you will have to use SteamWorks which means if your internet is crap and you want this game for LAN games you are screwed (even thought it says it is offered). Buy used versions of this game and the expansions (seriously like $2.50, a massive difference in price) and then plug in your cd key into Steam and get the Steam version for free while retaining your ability to play LAN games. You get more for much less currently by going used and plugging in the keys. Until the issues are fixed this game and its expansions are grossly overpriced. Amazing game, don't waste the money on the current Steam versions.**The game (Current Steam Version with update) is suffering from major online failures across the board. Don't buy the game hoping to jump into PvP as it looks to be broken and doesn't look to have a fix in sight.*Buying the expansion Tales of Valor will open up LAN options for networked PC's, the base game will not allow it. Also you will have to buy the expansions in order to play as the British.Gamplay:This game is the greatest to date RTS game surrounding the events of WWII and might even be the greatest RTS game of all time. They introduced many things into the genre that hadn’t been seen before and honestly haven’t really been seen since as the genre seems to be dying out. Instead of having to manage hundreds of villagers telling them to get wood/stone etc (building an economy), you build structures that produce units and capture and hold key points on the map that give you resources to build said units. Some features such as having all your units visible on a side bar plus all of your groups you have created clearly labeled on the same side bar (as group 1, 2, etc) is absolutely priceless. You will never lose track of any of your units ever again. Also the ‘retreat’ option; oh… my… word… THANK YOU! SO often in these games you just want to have your people FLEEEEE! You can in this, and they will run (faster than normal) straight back to your base (not really firing in the process BUT taking less damage). These features are huge improvements to such a stale genre.Another huge factor that plays into this game play is that THIS IS NOT A 20 MINUTE RUSH GAME! As far as Starcraft and AoE’s are played most games are over in 15 minutes with a rush; this game is all tactics. Someone rushes something there are huge counter measures where certain troops do terrible vs others so you cannot just rush a single unit and go; huge tactics in this game. The majority of the game play involves fighting over key points and ‘bleeding’ the enemy out of resources as you chip away at his defenses. Snipers, MG teams, rifle squads, etc make up the bulk of what you build; most of the units are in ‘squad’s or ‘groups’ vs just being alone and you have to bunch them up. Cover (in buildings and in the world) is important and has huge effects on who will win the battle. All in all an extremely well-polished RTS with well-polished RTS mechanics.  To see my thoughts on other games, movies, and music (and their complete reviews) check out my blog found in my Steam profile or by Google (Search Ashley and Micah English) Thanks.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												Inferior in every way to Dawn of War balance and AI. This eschews good RTS for gratifying the Idiocracy wave of gamers. Getting rid of real resource management makes the game more similar to Men of War; except CoH (both of them) suck compared to MoW at the tactical level. The complete lack of realism in the game also is a buzzkiller for any WW2 fan. Had they done something similar to their Dawn of War RTS games (not that DoW RPG wannabe RTS crap=DoW2) then this might have been a decent series. This game is best left to the insta-gratification console generation. More and more games have been getting dumbed down and require little brains, this series is an example of that. There are far better games out there that require much more intelligence and provide real gameplay. I'm afraid with this game all hope is lost for real RTS games made for adults instead of teenagers.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												Company of Heroes is the best frontline tactics game I've found, but it's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. The whole set should have their very own short bus. I own the whole Company of Heroes collection and let me give you this: only get COH: Opposing Fronts. The regular COH says that you must have COH: Tales of Valor. content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												This game was really good in the past and is still is sort of an amazing rts game. But currently there are so many problems with this game and it is sort of ruining the fun in the game and I'll explain them all.1. The gameplay is extremly unbalanced: Mostly in favor of the axis. The axis tanks can easily counter almost anything that the allies through at them. For all honesty Panzer Elite can be extremly op first of all and the british are not certainly a good balancing factor to help out the allies. Panzer Elite has scout cars almost within minutes of starting the game and they can capture points and wipe out squads of engineers easily trying to capture them. They also extremly OP artillery based tanks which can easily be manuevered while the allies do not have manueverable aritillery which and unbalances the game even more. Second some infantry notes the Knights Cross holders are THREE MEN and are capable of wiping out 2 or even 3 squads easily. Their health is too high for infantry units and they are impossible to stop when they are in a cluster of 20-30. In fact I find it easier in some cases to take out axis tanks as allies then knights cross holders. Point is they are too OP and the allies do not even have any infantry troops to successfully counter them. Second a problem with both sides is that snipers are so OP. They uncover themselves and can easily go back into hiding after shooting. In all honesty, the camoflague feature should be wiped out and maybe instead of an extremly long range of site in that snipers could hide in the fog of war but become visible when shooting which would add to realism and help balance for the fact that snipers can camp inside a base and just keep on firing aritillery at the enemy base without even coming out of sight.But to some up you almost start to forget that the Allies won World War 2 for the fact that the Germans always win matches and destroy the ally armies so easily.2. The community isn't that great anymore. The old veteran players are running the show and pretty much taking up all the axis slots and dominating with the OP armies. In fact you can barely pull any wins as the allies anymore unless the axis players are noobs which is extremly rare. Also the veteran players don't even want to play with noobs and you will probably get kicked out of the game or moved to allies and called a noob just because you won 4 out 39 matches as allies. Its like sort of the community is redefining the word all together in that a noob is just someone who sucks instead of someone who is new to the game.Also to note I did not buy this game off steam and in fact i had it pretty much since it came out. It transfered to the steam version and it says I have 2 versions of the game for some reason a (New Steam Version and Regular). I have 42 hours on record for the (New Steam Version) and probably over 100 before I added it on steam. I know this game extremly well and love it but this review is out of complete honesty that this game has turned awful.

number of helpful: 1 of 12 people (8%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												Before you read this you should know I have player Men Of War.WHAT I DIDN'T LIKE:It would be an awesome game if it wasn't for the fact it's so unreal.Tanks have healthbars like a MMORPG troll, and its damage barely varies from where it is hit.Tanks can't use HE for a reason. Which results in 2 minutes of missing one soldier.I miss the direct control over units, cause they REALLY like to put their backs toward enemies.I don't get the point why the enemy keeps getting Stugs and Pz, while all I can do is set up mines which takes forever, resulting in leaving me defenseless.I have no idea why units can't throw multiple grenades (must wait 5 seconds), and why are they infinite.Units cannot run for their lives when pinned but throw themselves right into enemy fire. Like it would save them.In general the game is hard to understand because it isn't made in a way anyone could easily understand.Soldiers are really a general "thing" without different weapons.I am not sure if they can take a couple of hits or are this bad at aiming.WHAT I DID LIKE:The cinematics, they remind me of Band Of Brothers a little, are well made and makes you kind of bond with the NPC soldiers.Loved the TF2/AoE2 reference hitting things makes other things.I wouldn't reccomend this game for anyone new to strategy games, nor a veteran who has many more better games.

number of helpful: 3 of 17 people (18%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 23, 2013
												The incessant scrolling, squad menus, stupid squad response,  the inability of these soldiers and squads under my command to stay out of my line of site, or evade the enemy and enemy fire are the standards of video games these days.  it's not MY unfamiliarity with the controls, or recognize the positions of each unit, it is how poorly they are identified, or their position. The bumbling stupidity of these troops to execute orders without tripping over one another, or obstructing one another is stupifying. It's like trying to run a painting company with the three stooges, except it's an entire army of stooges in a restricted locational overview.Add to the sheer stupidity of these guys the macros, keybinds, tactics incongruity, and building area restrictions, and you have another frustrating exercise trying to coordinate strategies with illogical menu interfaces.More and more, I see developers who can't place menus in smart locations away from the center, out of the way, without obstructing MY view. It is funny how the robot invaders range, and field of view advantages exceed my own, and they trap my stupid army in an ambush while they move intelligently and easily to surround us. I save a lot of money on games now, but can't get refunds for glitchy, clumsy interfaces, and unfair 'stupid logic' as the only thing I have to command.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												I did not enjoy this game, sadly after reading so many positive reviews all over the internet I decided to buy the complete pack.Firstly the AI is not good, even by 2006 standard.It feels too linear for it's scale. Not so many different ways to complete the objectives.You can't control individual soldiers, when they encounter a group of enemies they fire and throw grenades as they want to. You can control if they should hold fire or fire but nothing more in-depth than that.In a way it's Call of Duty in RTS form. Not very hard to learn, no complicated controls, your units can't do much more than move, cover and attack in one or two ways.It's a no-brainer to play. With all the pros and cons that come with it.The political symbols are censored (-historical accuracy) but there might be a mod texture for it.The effects and graphics are good for the game's age and the storyline is interesting at times.The environments are well made and adds abit of immersion.Most of the mission are defeat these enemies and capture this point or capture this point and get reinforcements, defend this position and get reinforcements and move on.I would recommend Men of War Assault Squad 1 or 2 instead. Bigger maps, indivdual unit and soldier control, more units, more destruction, more realistic, realistic damage to vehicles, more freedom of choice and good mod support.http://store.steampowered.com/search/?developer=Digitalmindsoft (Men of War link)

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												A terribly overrated game - absolutely atrocious:The AI is terrible it's like everyone in this world has obsessive-compulsive disorder: mortar crews will get stuck in a repeating pattern of setting up and taking down over and over again. tanks will expose their rear to fire when you expressly tell them to keep their front to enemy; your soldiers and armor will automatically attack the enemy that poses the least threat, while letting  themselves get pounded into the dirt by other NPCs...even after you tell them expressly which enemy to focus on.balancing is terrible - apparantely, the "rules" don't apply to the game itself...just the player: expect NPC enemies to come from off screen at any given time from any given point on the map, rendering carefully placed layers of defense meaningless; expect enemies to pop up from nowhere like little weeds that spawned from the dirt; expect a RPG team to be able to destroy your tanks, even while your tank is shooting every single gun it has at them....and missing every f--king bullet. Line of sight and fog of war apparently doesn't seem to apply to the enemy NPCs.But if you enjoy wasting your money and  time, and are some sort of masochist who gets off on frustration, then this game is for you

content:

												I have 800+ hours,I know this game is bad.What this entire game is based on is ranger spam and if the map will allow you to kite those rangers properly. You can only deselected so many maps(yep the game dictates what maps are best for you, like some tyrannical government that knows what's best). No wonder THQ went out of business.You can cover half of the maps by spamming mortors in your base, you don't need oil, just manpower for ranger spam. The vehicles can't even navigate properly unless you micro manage 3 of them all at once while kiting ranger spam(impossible and highly gimmicky).Even if do you manage the win, the opponent will likely call you a hacker for using an anti-tank half track to kill his squads.This game has nice graphics for when it was made.

Posted: July 21, 2013
												Clearly one of those games where the developers are meticulous in their testing. Even INCESSANT with it, perhaps?Either way, the results are plain to see.The end products are these highly fine-tuned game mechanics which allow you choose the type of commander you want to be, be it an infantry warlord, vehicle hero or support warrior. And yet, you're still able to compete with anyone and everyone, regardless of Which war Enthusiast you may choose to specialise in.One thing that many were concerned about on it's release was that Tanks would be able to moonwalk over everything. There was even concern that the infamous 1980's disco floor filler and megahit "Thriller", by the late, great, awe inspiring Michael Jackson, would come on every time someone used a tank. This is not the case at all, tanks are not invincible and can be destroyed using infantry. Infantry can do it. Trust me.

Posted: November 13, 2015
												This game... Is arguably 10 times better than the second. It's like playing Dawn of War 1, but instead the action takes place in 1944-45.Pros:- tons of units and customizability- 4 playable factions (with the expansions)- a competitive online system that will test your skills and patience- a very clear and easy to navigate hud- different game modes that keep things interesting and fresh- affordable priceCons:- less units than it's successor, albeit they won't cost you your soul to field- graphics look a bit dated compared to CoH2- you can't vault fences or walls... But you can blow'em up or just drive through themIf you ever find yourself on the crossroads between CoH 1 and 2 pick the former. It may not be updated as frequently but at least it's playable and serviceable and aside from two expansions you won't have to pay a dime to unlock/swap to newer units.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Hero. Who among us has ever been afforded the oppurtunity to meet an actual hero? Hero is a word that has been saturated as of late. Is a firefighter really a hero for saving that cat out of the tree? Mittens would in all likelihood have gotten down from that tree on his own, whether it be due to his own wishes, or the cruel hand of gravity. One could argue that a cat's life is not greater than or equal to in value of the cost of taxes being payed to fund the fire station. That one would be right. "But what about actual fires? Don't we need firefighters for that?" Great question.I know most people reading this review may find my beliefs to be quite inhumane, hell I doubt anyone will ever read my musings, but I can't sit upon the the hands that are my morals and wait for a hero to come along and save me. I have to step up to the proverbial batter's box, and proverbially knock the proverbial fastball of evil out of the proverbial ballpark. I challenge each and every one of you to do the same.Signing off, MattDamonsOwl.

Posted: January 11, 2014
												My RTS skills are weak at best which could impact my judgement on a RTS game. Still, I think this game is great.Unlike old school mechanics where you have to build a base and gather resources, CoH just requires you to capture strategic points which will continually give resources as long as they are held. Base building is also very simplified with only a few buildings required to build.All this makes the game more straightforward and with a emphasis on tactical warfare. It's Relic at their best.

Posted: June 4, 2014
												One of the best RTS games of all time. This games mechinics are a bit different then the average Command and Conqure or Starcraft base/army building. This game focuses on squads, instead of individual units, and it's through careful manuvering and stratagey with those units that this game truly shines. Resources are gained only through "Domination" Control points on the map. The history is acurate, afaik, and the detail in everything is stunning. If you haven't played this game and you consider yourself an RTS fan, then you had better pick this one up before anyone finds out your a faker.

Posted: May 25, 2014
												If you are a fan of WWII and fast-paced strategy games that require minimal focus on economy and more on military, then this is the game for you. Resources are granted through the acquisition of key points in the map that will provide you with 1 of 3 resources: manpower, munitions, and fuel. Even though these points are vital for the economy side of the game, taking and maintaining these points requires a lot of focus on the size and positioning of one's military. As far as military units go, the game is just like any RTS game. You have light (infantry), medium (light vehicles), and heavy units (tanks) and counter units to different units in those classes. There are also three different branches for the Allies and Axis factions to choose from that will support you in commanding your troops on the battlefield. Support such as off-map artillery, increased abilities for units, and special units can be utilized to give you that extra edge against the enemy. Like I said, I would recommend buying this game not only because of the gameplay, but the amazing graphics and audio are a definite plus to the gameplay experience. Happy gaming!

												Command and Conquer meet History. History meet CnC... wait what? Ignore that. However, there is base building, unit creation, unit promotions and research trees. Certanly sounds familiar. Posted: December 26, 2013
												This is an amazing RTS game that feels slightly different than ones that you might have already been accustomed to. One main aspect that differentiates this game from others is the Cover system. The system allows for your units to take cover in various enviromental objects, which an ingenious gameplay feature.Another difference is that buildings cannot be constructed around the map like in Age of Empires, Warcraft 3, Starcraft, etc.which leads to a different strategy of emcampment. All in all, this a game I'd say is worth buying and playing.

Posted: April 19, 2014
												Company of heroes is among the best RTS games I've played - having everything from small bouts between squads to full firefights across rivers involving heavily dug-in emplacements and well estasblished defenses. this game forces the player to make strategic decisions if they want to win the match, be it establishing a base of operations halfway up the field or blowing up bridges to cut off enemy movements across the river, and unless the player can adapt and react to everything and adapt to everything happening on the map, they will quickly lose control. Every firefight is carefully adjustable if the player knows what they're doing - when to use artillery and mortars, where to set up emplacements, and with the right strategy even the smallest, most wounded squad can beat back a small army. That's what makes this game special, is that the small squads still allow for massive action, especially when you're in an extended battle to take a fortified hill.However, it is not to be said that it's the eprfect game, as this game is incredibly brutal and will easily put off new players or players that aren't as good at RTS games and, to an extent, micromanagement, and it can even be daunting to players who are otherwise veterans in the RTS genre, due to all the new mechanics to which you must adjust.TL;DR: Company of Heroes is awesome if you can do tactics, not so much if you can't.

But that doesnt mean this game is bad, it just means its annoyingly difficult.Oh and dont try to cheat - The one time I simply had to turn off the game was because I built tank traps spanning the width of the map and the AI - instead of shooting them apart - drove through them, It was horrible to see but I guess if you cheat the AI will cheat back.

												Company of Heroes is a really good WW2 tactical squad-based RTS. The gameplay is somewhere between Dawn of War 1 and 2. Posted: October 25, 2011
												While I grew up on the C&C and C&C RA games, which I prefer, and wold like a new one that was actually great, this game still rocks and helps fill that void. The graphics are good, the explosions are fantastic! The sound is pretty good too! Music is typical WWII music for the most part, some tracks do stand out pretty good, but I turn the music down to bare minimum to enjoy the wonderful sound effects this game has.The performance is pretty good if you have a good rig, unless of course you level out the camera and look across a populated area thats decent in size. That will chop the Frames per second even the beastliest rigs. The gameplay is fantastic, pretty indepth game honestly. The base building leaves a lot to be desired, but the combat and movement itself is done very well! If you enjoy it then there are 2 expansions for it that will give you plenty more of it.I Just wish they would make a Vietnam or later themed game just like this! With better base building! Would be :)

Posted: May 8, 2011
												Command and Conquer meet History. History meet CnC... wait what? Ignore that. However, there is base building, unit creation, unit promotions and research trees. Certanly sounds familiar. But this is a game in its own league.With graphics hardcore enough to match to anything you get today and with an A.I that will ALSO♥♥♥♥♥♥your mother while you thought it was drinking tea in front of you. Its a challenge both for strategist and those who thought they are tough. Hours of fun with friends or against the computer.Controls are easy and most of its handled with point n click methods that appear with most RTS. Coupled together with Blitzkrieg mod, you've got yourself a fine WW2 strategy game that handles all your favourite things in one screen. Panzers, Infantry, point captures, stop salvating and get on in already.One small gripe I do have and its a minor one, when will the super units and structures appear that most RTS's have today? ;)Final Rating: 4.5 / 5

												This is one of the greatest RTS games I've ever played. I've been playing these kinds of games since the mid 90's. It all started with Command & Conquer for me. I have played quite a few  since then and not many have captured my interest as well as C&C did. C&C Red Alert 2 wrote the book on how to do a good RTS but I always wanted something more modern and reallistic. For a couple of years I gave up on RTS games in general. One too many bad experiences I guess. I recently picked up Company of Heroes during a steam sale and I was blown away. It is brilliant. A great look and style. Runs well on many different PCs. It is all that I've wanted in an RTS and more. It is set during WWII which I would rather have a little more modern but it works well as it is. I only have two complaints. 1. Enjoy.

Posted: March 16, 2012
												I think it's about time I recommend my 2nd favorite game of all time. Company of Heroes is plain fun, addicting and smart. You play CoH like chess. Every unit has a role and what they can be used to counter or push forward. The single player gets you ready for the multiplayer where most of the fun happens. You can either play skirmish agaist the AI or basic matches (pvp) of up to 4v4. The community is alive and friendly for the most part. You can gather tips and information about CoH on Gamereplays.org and watch videos for more strategies with Propagandacast and TheSoundStrategyNetwork on youtube. There are 3 major mods (Blitzkrieg,Eastern Front and Modern Combat) that make the game even better, adding new factions, trees, weapons, vehicles and gamepay mechanics. Overall, you will have tons of fun in the campaign and multiplayer. Even without multiplayer, this game is worth the $10 and deffinetly the $2 when it goes on sale. Do yourself and my crippled dog a favor and buy this game.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												I always thought that like your first pill of ecstacy, you'll never forget your first great gaming experience. As far as RTS titles go, Westwood's Command & Conquer Tiberian Dawn seemed to take a crowning influence over the genre - at least until this game came along. While I'll always associate C&C memes and references to those glorious Win 95 days of old, Company of Heroes delivers an RTS experience that gracefully walks the tightrope between realistic combat simulation and skin of your teeth strategic gameplay. While I won't address the benefits of a well-told WW2 storyline, one of the most unique contributions of this game to its genre, is its combat system which creates empathy for each individual soldier on a micro perspective, and the thrill of successfully executing combined-arms tactics with armour and support weapons on a macro scale. Play this game, and then play it online - because it is one of the very few titles to have redefined the war strategy genre.

												This game... Is arguably 10 times better than the second. It's like playing Dawn of War 1, but instead the action takes place in 1944-45.Pros:- tons of units and customizability- 4 playable factions (with the expansions)- a competitive online system that will test your skills and patience- a very clear and easy to navigate hud- different game modes that keep things interesting and fresh- affordable priceCons:- less units than it's successor, albeit they won't cost you your soul to field- graphics look a bit dated compared to CoH2- you can't vault fences or walls... But you can blow'em up or just drive through themIf you ever find yourself on the crossroads between CoH 1 and 2 pick the former. It may not be updated as frequently but at least it's playable and serviceable and aside from two expansions you won't have to pay a dime to unlock/swap to newer units.

Posted: March 16, 2012
												I think it's about time I recommend my 2nd favorite game of all time. Company of Heroes is plain fun, addicting and smart. You play CoH like chess. Every unit has a role and what they can be used to counter or push forward. The single player gets you ready for the multiplayer where most of the fun happens. You can either play skirmish agaist the AI or basic matches (pvp) of up to 4v4. The community is alive and friendly for the most part. You can gather tips and information about CoH on Gamereplays.org and watch videos for more strategies with Propagandacast and TheSoundStrategyNetwork on youtube. There are 3 major mods (Blitzkrieg,Eastern Front and Modern Combat) that make the game even better, adding new factions, trees, weapons, vehicles and gamepay mechanics. Overall, you will have tons of fun in the campaign and multiplayer. Even without multiplayer, this game is worth the $10 and deffinetly the $2 when it goes on sale. Do yourself and my crippled dog a favor and buy this game.

Posted: July 6, 2015
												This is a classic and still a lot of fun to play. Especially when you add the two additions to the game. While Company of Heroes 2 has better graphics and some improvements, this works great on older computers. If you don't already have this, add it to your collection--espcially when it goes on sale. This game has aged well. The hours listed only show what I have played on Steam. However, I played over 100 hours of this before it was on Steam when it was first released.

Posted: November 9, 2015
												Note: Hours are low because I mostly played the "New Steam version" that was made after THQ folded and Relic was sold to Sega. Steam lists it as a different game, but other than some Online features that were re-integrated into steam instead of THQ's servers, it's otherwise identical and included with your purchase. Now on to the review!In my humble opinion, the best RTS ever. Short form: Take Band of Brothers' brutally realistic take on World War 2 and give it to the best RTS devs in the buisiness.Have them craft a wide arrangement of viable strategies, reinforced by a Commander system that assists you in your chosen strategy (Yes you can successfully turtle! Provided you grab the points first!), mechanics that force you to consider positioning and cover over pure production, Warhammer 40k's Vehicle damage Mechanics (Hitting them from the side or rear means better chance of penetration and damaging components), and top it all off with amazing art and sound work.There's quite honestly, nothing I can think of in the RTS realm that tops this gem.If there was any letdown it is that the SP missions can drag on a bit too long and the strategy in this mode gets mindless at times (skirmish and online is a whole 'nother story!). Still fun, but when one of the bonus objectives is to finish a level in FIFTY minitues, there's a problem.  If you don't have the patience, just skip it and go to skirmish, and once you are comfortable with it's style, try it online.Also Opposing Fronts is worth it, British commonwealth and Panzer Elite are awesome factions. Also the campaigns are far better paced, Especially Panzer Elite's. Haven't tried (or bought) Tales of Valor so can't say how good that one is.

Posted: August 11, 2015
												***NOTE: Game played on New Steam Version, but reviewed on this version***As someone who isn't a big RTS fan, I focused my playtime on the Campaign. I thoroughly enjoyed the campaigns. While there is always going to be come degree of "build as many units as you can and throw them at your enemy", Company of Heroes felt like it had more to offer than that. There is a lot of strategy involved to ensure your campaign objectives. Which sectors to capture; where to build defences and what kind to build; what makeup should my forces be?The game felt very balanced, as no units or countries felt overpowered. The quality of your units were traded off well with their costs. A number of the units also have their own flavour dialogue which added a lot of character and humour to the game. The campaigns themselves had a nice flowing story to them, which was a nice surprise. If anything, I would have liked more story, but that probably shows my preference for story-driven games.Overall, a nice campaign that you don't need to be a hardcore RTS player to enjoy. If you do enjoy your RTS though, there are also skirmish and online gameplay to enjoy.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												I always thought that like your first pill of ecstacy, you'll never forget your first great gaming experience. As far as RTS titles go, Westwood's Command & Conquer Tiberian Dawn seemed to take a crowning influence over the genre - at least until this game came along. While I'll always associate C&C memes and references to those glorious Win 95 days of old, Company of Heroes delivers an RTS experience that gracefully walks the tightrope between realistic combat simulation and skin of your teeth strategic gameplay. While I won't address the benefits of a well-told WW2 storyline, one of the most unique contributions of this game to its genre, is its combat system which creates empathy for each individual soldier on a micro perspective, and the thrill of successfully executing combined-arms tactics with armour and support weapons on a macro scale. Play this game, and then play it online - because it is one of the very few titles to have redefined the war strategy genre.

Posted: November 13, 2015
												This game... Is arguably 10 times better than the second. It's like playing Dawn of War 1, but instead the action takes place in 1944-45.Pros:- tons of units and customizability- 4 playable factions (with the expansions)- a competitive online system that will test your skills and patience- a very clear and easy to navigate hud- different game modes that keep things interesting and fresh- affordable priceCons:- less units than it's successor, albeit they won't cost you your soul to field- graphics look a bit dated compared to CoH2- you can't vault fences or walls... But you can blow'em up or just drive through themIf you ever find yourself on the crossroads between CoH 1 and 2 pick the former. It may not be updated as frequently but at least it's playable and serviceable and aside from two expansions you won't have to pay a dime to unlock/swap to newer units.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Hero. Who among us has ever been afforded the oppurtunity to meet an actual hero? Hero is a word that has been saturated as of late. Is a firefighter really a hero for saving that cat out of the tree? Mittens would in all likelihood have gotten down from that tree on his own, whether it be due to his own wishes, or the cruel hand of gravity. One could argue that a cat's life is not greater than or equal to in value of the cost of taxes being payed to fund the fire station. That one would be right. "But what about actual fires? Don't we need firefighters for that?" Great question.I know most people reading this review may find my beliefs to be quite inhumane, hell I doubt anyone will ever read my musings, but I can't sit upon the the hands that are my morals and wait for a hero to come along and save me. I have to step up to the proverbial batter's box, and proverbially knock the proverbial fastball of evil out of the proverbial ballpark. I challenge each and every one of you to do the same.Signing off, MattDamonsOwl.

												Not the hardest RTS to play in the world, once you get to grips with the units and the cover systems etc its really easy to be effective with your army, online play is extremely fun in 2v2s etc working together to hold ground and wear down your enemy, theres alot of action in this game as it forces you to attack and hold constantly, doesnt require the fastest reactions in the world but its still a great game for what it does, DOW2 was released after this and was based on this game totally and it was a way lesser game then this. COH gets it just right. 1v1s are good also, probably one of the best RTS's of all time, the series needs to stay true to its self and the second full game will just be amazing.

Posted: October 20, 2015
												Best RTS game I've ever played in my life. It's so good that I didn't add "so far" at the end of the previous sentence.First of all, it's historically accurate in the campaign.Second, it is very balanced, so you don't loose your whole squad in a 16 second shootout, but they could get a better idea than automatic weapons missing 75% of the time.Thirdly, it's fun to play and when you win you have that really big win feeling but when you loose you get sort of dissapointed but you try again and don't become a super sad person for the rest of the day... except when you loose the last mission of Liberation of Caen after two hours of gameplay.Fourthly, it's extremely unique, you don't see strategies and battles of this type in other games. If you play internet games you may have noticed that many of them use extremely simular HUDs because it's such a good and unique HUD that really helps how the game is played. I can imagine other commanding stuff and how bad/difficult it would be with them, so the HUD is really good.Fifthly, it gives the most suitable amount of challenge and option I have ever heard of. Battles could take 5 hours for a pro to win, but yet necomers may look upon rubbles of the enemy base.Sixthly, why are you still reading this I just thought you would have bought it already! You haven't? Well get it (if you want to) and enjoy your underprised loot.

Posted: July 22, 2013
												A challenging game, Company of Heroes really does require you to think strategically and be proactive in your gameplay. Instead of just sitting back and researching and fortifying while hoarding resources as you can do in other Strategy games, Company of Heroes requires you to constantly push the line forward in order to keep control of your territory and its resource points. Dawn of War II players, please note that this is the same engine and gameplay style, so it doesn't take long to get used to. However, it does feature quite a lot more than DoW II, in that you can build base structures, further customise the loadouts of squads and use special abilities without the need for a Commander unit. Very good for multiplayer, Company of Heroes is definitely a game worth trying out. ***

Posted: July 13, 2014
												THIS IS MY PREVIOUS REVIEW WHEN I HATED THE GAME. YOU CAN READ IT BUT MY NEW REVIEW IS AFTER THE BELOW!I thought it was an extremely fun game. I loved the D-Day mission in campaign and even without the expansions it is an excellent game.UNTIL. i went on the game one time and found that ALL units and BASES were invisible. I tried everything and even looked solutions up on Youtube but to no avail. Sadly this game was a waste of my money and it is now unplayable because the enemies are invisible and it just ruins the once amazing Company of Heroes. I am now sort of hesitating to buy CoH 2 becuase it could happen with that game too and COH 2 is $50. So sadly this game was a waste of time and money and unless it gets fixed i won't and can't play the game again. But to wrap up on a good note, i had plenty (About 4 matches) of good times and it is an older game so i can't expect too much. Cya and hope the the gods it gets fixed. =)*EDIT*SO i reinstalled the game after deleting it and i happily found out that it didn't turn my men invisible. I replayed the 1st campaign 1st level but on the second level, ALL my men and enemy men were in T-Pose with their guns sticking out of there chests and to make it worst EVERYTHNG BUT THE GROUND WAS BLACK (Not bien racist). I couldnt see my objectives becuase a huge black wall would appear in front of it and it is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I will uninstall this game forever and go play Men of War Assault Squad, a REAL strategy game. MOWAS is soo much better than ths junk AND in MOWAS there is an editor, though complicated. This game is stupid and i will never waste money on sequels ore anything, even if it is on sale. SCREW THIS GAME*EDIT*Sorry i raged quite a bit when i wrote the review. Now 2 years after uninstalling i downloaded it again. The new steam version. And it worked perfect. i have played heaps already and i am soo happy my favourite strategy game is back in action! Thankyou whoever changed the game. U R the best!!!10/10Perfect

Posted: December 30, 2011
												A wonderful Real Time Strategy, Company of Heroes excels on almost evey aspect. The Axis and the Allies Factions are very different, creating diversity in game. The physics applied on the scenary destruction is amazing, and it feels satisfying when pieces and blocks fly away after you command a Tiger Tank to blow the building to hell. The cover system is easy to understand, easy to use, but it's extremely important during play. A squad behind (or inside) heavy cover can easily withstand various waves of multiples squads, while those outside cover will die easily. You have 3 trees for each faction, each one focusing on a different aspect, leading to three different ways of playing each faction.

Posted: July 3, 2014
												possibly the best RTS game ive played...yes the bots cheat and most likely can see everything your doing (No fog of war for them i guess) but it is an amazing game! although i wish the addons were less then the actual game...here are the reasons it is really good:MULTIPLAYER: probably shouldnt play this until you are really good...but it is the reason this game is so awesomeSTORY: amazingly made story and seamless possibilities for attacking...GRAPHICS: amazing...just completely detailed graphics from the scars and scratches on the road to the buildings infrastructure and damage as well as designing each characters face with animations as they lie in pain on the ground waiting for the medic to arrivePHYSICS: the physics in this game are possibly the most realistic thing about this game...everything you do effects your surroundings: vehicles when slamming into walls do damage to the structure and you can see that damage physically as well as tanks being able to run into walls knocking them down allowing you to ambush your enemyOVERALL: overall this is a great game and i highly recommend it to someone who is die-hard for RTS games!Alright this is an edit... the graphics part...it is the best graphics i have ever seen for a 2006 game (not better then newer games) but this could rival COD: Ghosts Graphics...i may be being dramatic but DAAANNNNNNGGGGGGG just HOW!?!?!

Posted: December 27, 2011
												If Supreme Commander is the most macro focused RTS, and Starcraft 1/2 the most micro focused, Company of Heroes is the most tactical focused. The squad cover and combat mechanics, projectile physics, directional modifiers, and a wealth of unique units and abilities make this game challenging, satisfying, and unique every single time you play it. For those looking to get into it late, you can't go wrong with the core CoH game. ToV adds the British and PE factions while OF adds a handful of alternative units to each side. With the American and Wehrmacht factions being the most fun to play and play against, and the alternative units being a mixed bag, don't feel obliged to get the expansions.

Posted: December 30, 2011
												A wonderful Real Time Strategy, Company of Heroes excels on almost evey aspect. The Axis and the Allies Factions are very different, creating diversity in game. The physics applied on the scenary destruction is amazing, and it feels satisfying when pieces and blocks fly away after you command a Tiger Tank to blow the building to hell. The cover system is easy to understand, easy to use, but it's extremely important during play. A squad behind (or inside) heavy cover can easily withstand various waves of multiples squads, while those outside cover will die easily. You have 3 trees for each faction, each one focusing on a different aspect, leading to three different ways of playing each faction.

Posted: October 11, 2012
												I have been a Fan of THQ for a long time, and this title represents their Online RTS style gaming to a perfect profile. The core game content has a vast amount of replayability, introducing multiplayer gaming provides an additional facet of gameplay as well. The Mod community has openly accepted COH into their bosom, and produces fantastic Mods to the game, improving the style and playability in a fashion which was widely accepted and advocated by the community. This game is a great time killer, with rounds lasting on average 30+ min. The only downside is having to purchase the additional base content, now seeming worthless with the dawn of COH2 on the horizon. Still a top shelf RTS, for a reasonable price, with a contemporary loyal fan base.

Posted: May 12, 2012
												Very neat RTS. The WWII setting made me think of generic FPS things, but there's not really been much RTS' set in the times FPS' usually are, when you think about it. At least, none that are popular.Anyway, it's got standard RTS elements. Bases, units, strategising positions and flanking. The best part about it for me is that most functions are set to units rather than bases, so your bases are in general a little short staffed, while you send all of your manpower out to shot da bad gais.Campaign is your general D-Day thing that you'd expect from a WWII era game. It's fun to do it from a commanding perspective for once, and while some may argue against me for this, it's also nice they're not trying too hard to draw you into a story. It sets up the show, and you set off the fireworks.I should also note that the expansions do NOT require this original game, too. It's a neat idea, since I can now play the same game through three different Steam links with the extra stuff.

Posted: January 13, 2014
												Classic RTS game, WW2 themed Build & Conquor game with a very good replay value as you can do singleplayer missions, player vs computer skirmishs on multiplayer maps and player vs player games. Emphasis on Tactics and teamwork, this game sets the bar for all RTS games, not very large scale but very fun game with great game mechanics and very fun gameplay styles. (WARNING) orignal sever providers have closed the online server but STEAM has saved the day by providing a steam version that continues online service for this game.

Posted: January 13, 2014
												Oh yes.I love CoH, it's the perfect example of a game I'd play day and night (and I do just that).In my book, it's a 9/10 game for sure. Besides the awesome next-gen graphics and audio (from 2007), the gameplay gets the golden hot doge award. There hasn't ever been a game with so much flexibility and open-endedness as CoH. If the terrain gets mangled from annoying♥♥♥♥♥Kraut artillery and your troops don't have cover, then it's time to build some cover! The terrain is very malleable and destructible; bridges, buildings, fences, hedges, people, trees, you can blow it all up! Or if you want to hold the line, fortify it! It's a dream come true for a strategy lover like me. Oh, that's another thing. Even though the AI is sketchy at times, strategy is a big key to success. The AI has a bad habit of spamming ungodly and relentless amounts of tanks or infantry (or both) should you provide the resources to them, so it can become a bit strategy-lacking at times unless you're an antisocial person who likes fighting computers. I love RTS games with all of my heart, yes so sweet and beautiful it is to command armies of people and watch them fight to the death. I do find the unit selections a bit "limited" even though it's all you need to survive and get the job done. This is where the glory of mods come in! Mods add countless new units and functions into the game, a few even add new factions! Don't like something about the game or a mod? That's not a problem, learning how to mod the game yourself is easier than remembering 3.1415926535897932384!I've wasted days playing this game and I'm glad to have wasted my time with such a fun game. It's a legendary game in the world of RTS, and it remains my favorite RTS in the world to this day.

Posted: May 12, 2012
												Very neat RTS. The WWII setting made me think of generic FPS things, but there's not really been much RTS' set in the times FPS' usually are, when you think about it. At least, none that are popular.Anyway, it's got standard RTS elements. Bases, units, strategising positions and flanking. The best part about it for me is that most functions are set to units rather than bases, so your bases are in general a little short staffed, while you send all of your manpower out to shot da bad gais.Campaign is your general D-Day thing that you'd expect from a WWII era game. It's fun to do it from a commanding perspective for once, and while some may argue against me for this, it's also nice they're not trying too hard to draw you into a story. It sets up the show, and you set off the fireworks.I should also note that the expansions do NOT require this original game, too. It's a neat idea, since I can now play the same game through three different Steam links with the extra stuff.

Posted: July 3, 2011
												It's awesome.Graphics: A little dated, but nonetheless good. Actually, surprisingly good, considering how old the game is. Animations are amazing, as you'll see your Rangers reload their Thompsons (yes, the magazine actually do come out!!) and the facial expressions on your wounded soldiers as they cry out for a medic (..even though you can't hear it..xD). It just brings the battlefield to life. 8/10Gameplay: It's just plain fun. It doesn't take too long to build up your army and send them off to battle. It's entertaining to watch you and your allies crush the opponent in a head-first attack, but you can also take your units (as some are made in fireteams) and strategically conduct smaller-scale mini operations to take out certain targets. The ways to play are virtually inifinite and you'll find that it's possible to counter any strategy. There are the cons, but Steam isn't going to let me write them, and it's not like you'll read this anyways...

Posted: October 5, 2014
												Even with WW2 (especially with the Normandy landing and race to Berlin here in the U.S.) being beaten by a dead horse this game shines as probably the most streamlines and tactical RTS to date. Check the date, I'm writing this well after COH2 came out. This game is better and involves more thought, where in COH2 your only option in most missions is to steamroll through the enemy with more troops. Historically accurate? Yes... Satisfying? Not really. So check out this game if you are a strategy fan. You will not be dissapointed. Pick up the free "The Great War 1918" mod on steam. It's amazing. Don't let the hours I played on steam fool you. I played this game for dozens of hours from a storebought copy years ago.

												Company of Heroes is an excellent World War II-based RTS by the makers of DAwn of War. It's very well done and is a great deal of fun in both singleplayer and multiplayer. I recommend it to anyone. The price it's offered at makes it an even more compelling buy. The Opposing Fronts expansion pack is not vital, but it adds two great campaigns with two new factions.

												Company Of Heroes is one of the best strategy games I have ever played in a while, the great atmosphere, the great gameplay mechanics which combine cover-based combat and real time strategy, the fact that you cannot just overun an enemy position and have to outmaneuver or flank the position that is being defended. 												It's awesome. Great game with lots of replayability. Pros:really addicting gameplaythe RTS gameplay is great and fungreat to play with friendsrequires some good strategic play and thinkingallows for different play stylesGood (and historical) campaignthe DLCs ACTUALLY make the game better (i had to wash my hands after writing that)Slight Cons ( I really cant think of anything that I hate about this game): AI likes to spam AT gunsonline against humans can get pretty boring (everyone builds up defenses like crazy then arty spams then tank moshes)prepare yourself for at least an hour-long game at a time (pretty well worth it though)
